repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Continuing to Pythonize Сython documentation!

This PR Pythonises [this](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/strings.html) documentation page.

Lots of process details and standardization are found here: #4187

comment_data.body: pretty sure that tests will fail on that if we will uncomment this (look #4388)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@
+from cython.cimports.libc.stdlib import malloc
+from cython.cimports.libc.string import strcpy, strlen
+
+hello_world = cython.declare(cython.p_char, 'hello world')
+n = cython.declare(Py_ssize_t, strlen(hello_world))
+
+
+# @cython.cfunc  # https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4388
+def c_call_returning_a_c_string() -> cython.p_char:

comment_data.body: same
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@
+from cython.cimports.libc.stdlib import malloc
+from cython.cimports.libc.string import strcpy, strlen
+
+hello_world = cython.declare(cython.p_char, 'hello world')
+n = cython.declare(Py_ssize_t, strlen(hello_world))
+
+
+# @cython.cfunc  # https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4388
+def c_call_returning_a_c_string() -> cython.p_char:
+    c_string: cython.p_char = cython.cast(cython.p_char, malloc(
+        (n + 1) * cython.sizeof(cython.char)))
+
+    if not c_string:
+        return cython.NULL  # malloc failed
+
+    strcpy(c_string, hello_world)
+    return c_string
+
+
+# @cython.cfunc  # https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4388
+def get_a_c_string(c_string_ptr: cython.pp_char,

There is `c_func.pxd`

comment_data.body:
I think it'd be more useful for the documentation to say "cython.cfunc is unnecessary here because the pxd file makes it a C-function".

I don't think the documentation needs to draw attention to the issue, or that having `cfunc` is so essential to understanding the code that it needs to remain as a comment.

comment_data.body:
I don't think that we should leave that part in that way, it is only a temporary version. I can't say right now how should it be changed tho.

But if we will remove all annotations (either remove all or none) and will leave the comment why this part is not annotated then it still should reference the issue

comment_data.body: I'm not sure, so I need someone else to check if this is correct :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -221,13 +284,22 @@ general idea here is to be liberal with input by accepting any kind of
 byte buffer, but strict with output by returning a simple, well adapted
 object.  This can simply be done as follows:
 
-.. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/string/return_memview.pyx
+
+.. tabs::
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/string/return_memview.py
+
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/string/return_memview.pyx
+
 
 For read-only buffers, like :obj:`bytes`, the memoryview item type should
 be declared as ``const`` (see :ref:`readonly_views`). If the byte input is
 actually encoded text, and the further processing should happen at the
 Unicode level, then the right thing to do is to decode the input straight
-away.  This is almost only a problem in Python 2.x, where Python code
+away.  This is almost only a problem in Python 2.x (only?), where Python code
 expects that it can pass a byte string (:obj:`str`) with encoded text into
 a text API.  Since this usually happens in more than one place in the
 module's API, a helper function is almost always the way to go, since it

comment_data.body: I guess that this is never meant to be run from python, so it's ok to have `PY_MAJOR_VERSION` and `unicode` but I still don't like that `unicode` here, if we wanna switch to py3 (`language_level=3`) as default don't we have to change this to something else?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@
+from cython.cimports.cpython.version import PY_MAJOR_VERSION
+
+# @cython.cfunc  # https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2529
+def _text(s) -> unicode:
+    if type(s) is unicode:
+        # Fast path for most common case(s).
+        return cython.cast(unicode, s)
+
+    elif PY_MAJOR_VERSION < 3 and isinstance(s, bytes):
+        # Only accept byte strings as text input in Python 2.x, not in Py3.
+        return cython.cast(bytes, s).decode('ascii')
+
+    elif isinstance(s, unicode):
+        # We know from the fast path above that 's' can only be a subtype here.
+        # An evil cast to <unicode> might still work in some(!) cases,
+        # depending on what the further processing does.  To be safe,
+        # we can always create a copy instead.
+        return unicode(s)
+
+    else:
+        raise TypeError("Could not convert to unicode.")

comment_data.body: Since we're explicitly looking at the Python major here, I think `str` would be less clear.

comment_data.body:
ok well, should we change `unicode` to `str` this time?
(for the context [comment](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4389#discussion_r725496417))
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,9 @@
+# define a global name for whatever char type is used in the module
+char_type = cython.typedef(cython.uchar)
+
+@cython.cfunc
+def _chars(s) -> char_type[:]:
+    if isinstance(s, unicode):
+        # encode to the specific encoding used inside of the module
+        s = cython.cast(unicode, s).encode('utf8')
+    return s

comment_data.body:
I don't know how it wasn't caught by CI (via cythonizing examples), but it's present for like 9 years be80325538d977478f04f4002b49f7fd284ed3ed

Cython 3.0.0a8 doesn't allow cythonizing this because `no suitable method found`
and it seems right, there's no method for converting python object to cpp string, only python bytes

So I need to ask @scoder about the correctness of that
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6,7 +6,6 @@ def get_bytes():
     py_bytes_object = b'hello world'
     cdef string s = py_bytes_object
 
-    s.append('abc')
+    s.append(b'abc')
     py_bytes_object = s
     return py_bytes_object
-

comment_data.body:
IMHO, users should only have one place where types are defined. Either directly in the source file or in a .pxd file. Mixing both is just asking for annoyance.

We can add a code comment that makes it clear that the function is actually defined as a `cdef` function in the corresponding .pxd file – in case that's a) relevant enough and b) not clear from the surrounding text. Given that the topic is strings, we might fail on a).

comment_data.body:
I guess it only fails for you because you are compiling it with `-3`. It works with both `-2` and `--3str`.
Not sure which is better. It's probably ok to explicitly use a byte string here.

I don't think it helps readers to have this variable typed.
```suggestion
    return_all = (data[0] == 108)
```

comment_data.body:
What's interesting, without changing `unicode` to `str` it won't work even with `cython.unicode` because of the `if type(s) is unicode`

It won't run in python either way

One option is to replace `unicode` with `str`, nobody is using unicode anyways nowadays, the code that was written a long time ago will still work and people who's supporting it will know what to do with it, I think, on the contrary the new users will only be confused

Second options is to make a remark about the fact that this will ru only in python 2

And probably the best way is to do both, but leave the unicode version be, while having a str version as the first thing people see in the docs

repo.name: cython

title: Pythonise Unicode and passing strings (strings.rst)
